headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be are conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the BlackRock, Inc. First Quarter 2017 Earnings Teleconference. Our hosts for today's call will be Chairman and Chief Exec
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be are conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the BlackRock, Inc. First Quarter 2017 Earnings Teleconference. Our hosts for today's call will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Laurence D. Fink; Chief Financial Officer, Gary S. Shedlin; President, Robert S. Kapito; and General Counsel, Christopher J. Meade. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Meade, you may begin your conference.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. I'm Chris Meade, the General Counsel of BlackRock. Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that during the course of this call, we may make a number of forward-looking statements. We call your attention to the fact tha
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. I'm Chris Meade, the General Counsel of BlackRock. 
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that during the course of this call, we may make a number of forward-looking statements. We call your attention to the fact that BlackRock's actual results may, of course, differ from these statements. 
As you know, BlackRock has filed reports with the SEC, which lists some of the factors that may cause the results of BlackRock to differ materially from what we say today. BlackRock assumes no duty and does not undertake to update any forward-looking statements. 
So with that, I'll turn it over to Gary.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris, and good morning, everyone. It's my pleasure to present results for the first quarter of 2017. Before I turn it over to Larry to offer his comments, I'll review our financial performance and business results. While our earnings release di
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris, and good morning, everyone. It's my pleasure to present results for the first quarter of 2017. 
Before I turn it over to Larry to offer his comments, I'll review our financial performance and business results. While our earnings release discloses both GAAP and as-adjusted financial results, I will be focusing primarily on our as-adjusted results. 
BlackRock's competitive position has allowed us to continuously invest from a position of strength and to adapt and change our business model, always with the goal of being prepared to deliver outcomes for clients by leveraging a comprehensive set of technology and risk management capabilities. This strategy has fostered deeper client relationships and led to a differentiated and more consistent level of organic growth. 
BlackRock's first quarter results reflect an $80 billion of long-term net inflows, representing an annualized organic asset growth rate of 7% and an annualized organic base fee growth rate of 5%, highlighting the value of these investments and the success of our broad-based global technology and investment platform. 
Flows were positive across product type, client type and region. 
First quarter revenue of $2.8 billion was 8% higher than a year ago, and despite cost associated with the repositioning of our active equity business, operating income of $1.2 billion grows 10%. Earnings per share of $5.25 were up 24% compared to a year ago, driven also by higher nonoperating results and a lower effective tax rate in the current quarter. 
Nonoperating results for the quarter reflected $42 million of net investment gains, an increase from the first quarter of 2016 due to higher marks in the current quarter. First quarter net interest expense included $14 million of called premium expense associated with the current quarter's successful refinancing of our $700 million, 6.25% notes, which were called prior to their September 2017 maturity. Our issuance of $700 million of 10-year notes yielding 3.25% will result in a reduction of $21 million of annual interest expense going forward. 
Our as-adjusted tax rate for the first quarter was 23.8% compared to 29.6% a year ago and included an $81 million discrete tax benefit associated with the adoption of new accounting items related to stock-based compensation that were divested during the quarter. We continue to estimate that 31% remains a reasonable projected tax run rate for the remainder of 2017 though the actual effective tax rate may differ as a consequence of additional discrete items and tax law changes that could arise during the year. 
First quarter base fees were 7% year-over-year, driven primarily by the positive impact of market appreciation and organic growth on our average assets under management. 
On a constant currency basis, we estimate that base fees were approximately 9% year-over-year. 
Sequentially, base fees were up 2%. Growth in both year-over-year and sequential base fees was partially offset by the impact of a lower day count in the first quarter of 2017. 
Performance fees of $70 million increased $36 million from the first quarter of 2016, reflecting better hedge fund and loan-only performance but declines $59 million from the fourth quarter of 2016 primarily due to seasonally higher fees from funds with performance measurement period that ended in the fourth quarter. 
Aladdin revenue up $158 million was up 12% year-over-year, driven by new clients and several sizable implementations going live on the Aladdin platform over the last year. 
Internally, we recently realigned Financial Markets Advisory, or FMA business, the Client Solutions and the BlackRock Investment Institute to offer clients a more cohesive and comprehensive advisory service. To better align our external reporting in light with this change, Aladdin revenue, previously reported within the BlackRock Solutions and advisory line item on our income statement will now be presented as technology and risk management revenue on our P&L. 
Advisory revenue associated with our FMA business will now be combined with other revenue and included as part of an advisory and other revenue line item. Technology is changing how the world invest and how we interact with clients. We continue to see strong market demand for institutional Aladdin, Aladdin Risk for Wealth Management, FutureAdvisor and other technology solutions as client seeks sophisticated risk analytics and portfolio construction tools. This new presentation, which is reflected in our first quarter income statement, is intended to sharpen the focus and our technology and risk management businesses at BlackRock. 
Total expense increased 6% year-over-year and 1% sequentially driven by higher compensation of volume-related expense, lower G&A expense and $22 million of certain onetime expense associated with the recently announced strategic repositioning of our active equity platform. 
Employee compensation and benefit expense was up $78 million or 8% year-over-year, reflecting higher incentive compensation, driven primarily by higher performance fees and higher operating income and approximately $20 million of severance and accelerated compensation expense associated with the repositioning of the active equity platform. 
Sequentially, compensation and benefit expense was up 4%. Reflecting these repositioning costs, higher seasonal payroll taxes and an increase in stock-based compensation expense related to new 2017 brands, partially offset by lower incentive compensation resulting from seasonally lower performance fees and operating income in the current quarter. 
G&A expense was down 5% year-over-year, primarily reflecting lower discretionary marketing and promotional spend. 
Sequentially, G&A expense decreased $54 million from the fourth quarter or 15%, primarily reflecting the seasonal impact of lower marketing and promotional expense in the first quarter and reduced foreign exchange remeasurement expense. 
Aggregate G&A expense for the first quarter also benefited from a delay in the timing of certain expense items, including marketing and promotional expense, which we anticipate will be incurred throughout the remainder of 2017.  Assuming stable markets, we continue to expect a modestly higher level of full year G&A spend in 2017 as compared to 2016. 
Our first quarter as-adjusted operating margin of 42.6% was up 100 basis points year-over-year, reflecting a continued focus on striking appropriate balance between investing for future growth and practical discretionary expense management. We remain committed to leveraging the benefits of our scale for both clients and shareholders. 
We also remain committed to using our cash flow to optimize shareholder value by first reinvesting on our business and then returning excess cash to shareholders. In line with that commitment, we previously announced a 9% increase in our quarterly dividend to $2.50 per share of common stock and also repurchased an additional $275 million worth of shares in the first quarter. We stand by previous guidance as it relates to share repurchases for the remainder of the year. 
First quarter long-term net inflows of $80 billion were positive across client types and diversified across asset classes and regions. Long-term net inflows benefited from significant flows into iShares as both institutional and retail clients increased their use of ETFs as the building blocks for their portfolios and in combinations to drive active returns. 
Globalized shares generated record quarterly net inflows of $64 billion, representing 20% annualized organic growth, driven in part by an accelerating global shift to fee-based advisory and the wealth channel and by rapid adoption of iShares' ETFs as financier instruments by professional money managers.
iShares captured the #1 share of first quarter industry globally in the U.S., Europe and in equity and fixed income with our U.S. iShares franchise crossing over $1 trillion in assets under management for the first time.
 iShares' equity net inflows of $45 billion reflected demand for core ETFs across both developed and emerging market exposures and strong inflows into higher fee precision exposures and smart beta ETFs. Fixed income iShares' net inflows of $20 billion were led by flows into investment-grade corporate and emerging market bond funds. 
Our institutional business generated $11 billion of long-term net inflows in the first quarter, driven primarily by indexed inflows. 
Institutional active net outflows of $1 billion reflected net outflows of equity and fixed income, partially offset by inflows into multi-asset and alternatives. Multi-asset flows were driven by our LifePath target-date series which saw a $5 billion of net inflows in the quarter, the strongest flow quarter in recent history. Excluding return of client capital, institutional alternatives generated over $2 billion of net inflows reflecting deployment of committed capital in infrastructure and private equity and hedge funds solutions. 
Momentum in alternatives is continuing, evidenced by yet another strong fundraising quarter for illiquids as we raised more than $2 billion of new commitments. Illiquid alternatives remain a key growth area for BlackRock as further demonstrated by our recent announcement of the acquisition of the first reserve infrastructure funds. We expect this acquisition to close later this quarter, bringing total invested and committed infrastructure capital to approximately $14 billion. 
Retail net inflows of $5 billion were led by inflows into fixed income and indexed equity products, partially offset by outflows from world allocation strategies. Fixed income net inflows of [ $5 million ] were diversified across our top-performing platform and included $2 billion of inflows into unconstrained strategies as well as strong flows into emerging markets and municipals. 
In addition, our multi-asset income strategy raised $1 billion during the first quarter as investors continue to target specific income-oriented outcomes. 
Our first quarter financial and business results reflect the benefits in the investments we've made to evolve our global distribution, investment in technology platforms ahead of developing client needs and industry trends. Diversification, whether investment style, distribution channel, product or region and scale created truly advantage competitive position that will enable us to continue making strategic investments with a goal of delivering long-term value for clients and shareholders alike. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Larry.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call. BlackRock first quarter results were a reflection of a purple sold investments we have made for our first 29 years to create the broadest investment platform in the asset manageme
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call. 
BlackRock first quarter results were a reflection of a purple sold investments we have made for our first 29 years to create the broadest investment platform in the asset management industry, complemented by global distribution network and industry-leading technology. 
Our full range of investment strategies was strength in index, factors, smart beta, quantitative and fundamental active and alternatives uniquely positioned BlackRock to develop a more holistic relationship and connect deeper with our clients. Our strong results this quarter are not a result of what we did over the last 3 months, but really a result over our long-term strategy. We have always kept our focus on a long-term, working to understand the evolution of the asset management ecosystem and the anticipate changes in our clients' needs so that we can adapt ahead of change and better meet their needs. 
For this reason, clients today rely on BlackRock not only for investment solutions, but also for our insights and guidance on how to navigate the global investment landscape. 
Over the past year, global events have had a significant impact in markets and investor sentiment. Following the presidential election, U.S. equity markets surged to an all-time high, driven by expectations for fiscal stimulus and regulatory reform and reflation expectations have been steadily increasing. However, there's still uncertainty, uncertainty about our health care, uncertainty about tax and trade reform, when they will ultimately be implement it in the United States and investor confidence has partially changed their significant issues related to tax reform, infrastructure spending, and so we need to see how this all involves. We are still optimistic, but we have to see how these all evolve. 
Strong first quarter equity returns have been driven by a synchronized recovery in global economic growth with the sharpness recovery seen internationally. However, it is unclear how social and political agendas will play out, particularly in Europe ahead of several elections, which is creating even more market anxiety. 
Furthermore, as the dollar remains strong following a period a significant appreciation, we could see further headwinds for dollar-based investors with global portfolios. 
Despite recent action by the Federal Reserve, the impact to sustain low rates at our clients portfolios will continue. Many clients today are struggling to meet their liability needs, and this will likely to continue and will likely remain a challenge. 
As I talked about in my recent Chairman's letter to our shareholders in our Annual Report, at the heart of BlackRock is a culture that embraces change. We, as an organization, we anticipate, we prepare, and we transform change into opportunities. 
As the landscape for asset managers evolve, a challenging narrative has emerged across the industry, one of managers having to play defense to protect themselves from market headwinds, structural changes and fee pressure. The reason much of the asset management industry is in defensive is that many managers are not evolved and they're playing catch up. We build BlackRock differently. Evolution is a part and a critical part of our culture. 
Throughout our history, we're focused on identifying political trends. We anticipated how those trends will impact our clients' needs and then we pivot our business accordingly. 
As a result, we build [indiscernible] equipped with investment strategies and technology, one that is agile. We seek to adapt change -- we seek to adapt ahead of change, not in response to it. However, we also recognize that sometimes, we make a misstep and addressing those quickly as just as important. 
BlackRock has a full range of investment strategies, from market cap weighted index exposures at one end, to a illiquid alternatives at the other and everything in between. We've created technology capable of bringing those building blocks together to design and deliver outcomes for our clients, and we built unmatched scale that strategically positions us to create value for our clients and our shareholders. 
Now is the time more than ever for BlackRock to play offense. Our scalable investment in technology platform is our greatest durable competitive advantage. And going forward, we will continue to identify opportunities to use our advantaged market position to create better financial futures for clients and drive long-term growth for shareholders. 
We're using our scale to lower prices for clients and drive growth and market share increases for BlackRock and our U.S. iShares core ETFs. We're using our scale to create more efficient relationships with our service providers. And earlier this year, we announced our plans to move $1 trillion of custodial assets. 
We're using our scale to build industry-leading technology to optimize investment performance and outcomes for our clients. We're using our scale to enhance our talent profile by tapping into a diverse network. And we're using our skills to make tactical, filling out acquisitions that further enhances our platform, our technology capabilities and our geographic reach. 
This approach is widening our competitive advantage and driving our ability to generate consistent strong organic growth. And we're going to continue to press our competitive advantage going forward, always with the best interest of our clients and our shareholders. 
In the first quarter, BlackRock generated $80 billion of long-term net inflows, representing a 7% annualized organic growth. Closer positive across product types, client types in all our regions. Record ETF flows were tangible example of the fundamental change we see in the ecosystem of wealth management and capital markets. 
Simple building blocks like iShares core is a strategic holding for long-term investors. Fixed income ETFs along side bonds for institutions, large asset owners taking greater control of portfolio risk profiles with factor-based ETFs, and and more and more investors are using a combination of ETFs to generate active returns. 
The investment landscape is changing and BlackRock is investing in iShares to lead industry growth in evolution. iShares saw a record first quarter inflows of $64 billion as clients saw ETFs in their portfolio, both for index exposures and as building blocks to deliver Alpha. 
Last October, we anticipated key changes impacting our retail and institutional clients that would change the way large pools of assets will be managed. We made a deliberate strategic investment in our U.S. iShares core ETFs, positioning this business to offer the highest quality product at the best value for our clients. This strategy is working, posting organic revenue and asset growth that exceeded our expectations. 
Since this strategic repricing, we have seen acceleration in growth in our iShares U.S. core ETFs with $52 billion of net inflows representing a 50% annualized organic growth. 
We've experienced a sizable uptick in our core market share, and we have recaptured more than 50% of the revenue impact through organic growth alone. 
Several years ago, we anticipated growing interest from our clients and factors in smart beta. Those strategies remain a significant area of focus for BlackRock, and BlackRock is positioned to win. We saw $2 billion in net inflows into BlackRock's smart beta ETFs in the first quarter, contributing to the total factor-based net inflows of $3 billion in our first quarter. The combination of our technology platform, our distribution connectivity, our commitment to risk management and our broad investment platform will enable us to be a leader in this space. 
We believe in active management more than ever before, especially in less efficient market where returns are less correlated. But we believe going forward, clients will be looking for different ways and different things from Active Equity and Alpha will need to be generated in the new ways. 
In October, we refined and expanded our active fixed income platform. 90% of our U.S. fixed income mutual fund platform now offers top quartile performance and top quartile pricing. I constrain product ranges also is well positioned for a rising rate environment, and we're beginning to see momentum with over $2 billion in net inflows in the quarter. 
As active equity management is being reshaped by massive investments in technology and data science and clients are focusing more in outcomes, we recently revitalized our active equity platform so that we are in a position to officially and consistently deliver investment performance to our clients. We segmented our product offerings into a range of strategies that span different levels of Alpha generation and value with appropriate manufacturing cost for BlackRock, and we are harnessing the power of people in technology as we lean into supporting both our fundamental and our quantitative equity managers with a shared data science and technology capabilities. We believe that levering our global scale and technology, we can drive better outcomes for our clients and future growth for BlackRock. 
At the end of the quarter, 65% of our fundamental active equities at 85% of our scientific active equity assets were above benchmark or paramedian for the 3-year period. 
The investments that we made in iShares, in our active fixed income and in our active equity is about leveraging our breadth, our scale and our technology to reap the benefits of our competitive advantages to drive growth. And we will continue to find ways to lever those unique strengths. 
As we look for other opportunities evolve for our clients, alternatives remain a key area of focus as our clients increasingly are searching for additional source of income and hopefully, uncorrelated returns. We saw another strong fundraising quarter with $2 billion of commitments, and we now have more than $12 billion uninvested committed capital to invest going forward across our $100 billion core alternative platform. 
We continue to advocate for infrastructure investing and support of policies to unlock private capital which offer multiple benefits, including providing new sources of return for investors, creating jobs, improving productivity and increasing capacity for long-term economic growth. 
Today, we manage $30 billion in real assets, and we expect this to continue area of growth BlackRock. 
As we look to enhance BlackRock's global credit platform, last month, we brought in Tim O'Hara to lead BlackRock's Credit business alongside Jim Keenan. Believe that the combination of BlackRock's long established presence and expertise in fixed income and our growing alternative platform positions us to be a leading provider in both liquid and illiquid credit, which provides attractive risk-adjusted opportunity for our clients who are seeking differentiated sources of income. 
While technology has always been a key differentiator for BlackRock, it is more essential to our business than ever before. We believe technology can transform our industry with enhanced technology and risk management helping investors achieve better outcomes. And we, at BlackRock, are leading the transformation. Our goal is to be the most sophisticated user of data and technology in the financial services industry. We seek to transform and integrate the way assets and wealth managers are creating client outcomes through portfolio construction, asset allocation, risk management and digital distribution. 
Our Aladdin technology is being used by more than clients than ever before with revenues growing 12% year-over-year and demand for Aladdin's multi-asset capabilities by institutions globally, especially in Europe and Latin America, remains strong. 
We also continued to see momentum in retail demand for Aladdin as interest continues to increase for Aladdin risk for wealth manager, which provides intermediaries with institutional quality portfolio of construction, modeling and risk management technology.  We are currently implementing a handful of clients in this technology in the United States, in Europe and in Asia. 
Aladdin remains in the only integrated investment risk management system on the market, and we believe this differentiation will continue to drive the attractive value oppositions and premium price points. 
In line with a commitment to technology, we recently nominated Chuck Robbins to our Board of Directors. Chuck has helped global corporations navigate a world being reshaped by technology advancements. We have consistently and consciously developed our board with the eye towards the future, and Chuck brings a deep understanding of technology promise to our board at a critical time for BlackRock. 
Building on record total net inflows of $202 billion in 2016, we began 2017 by continuing to invest in our business to capture the opportunities ahead of us, to drive continued growth and to aggressively leverage the benefits of our scale. We are transforming the change around us into the opportunities for the future, finding new methods to generate sustainable Alpha, using technology in innovative ways, building on our platform to serve our clients' evolving needs, creating continued opportunities for our employees and delivering consistent returns for our shareholders. 
Now let's open up for questions.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Larry, in a Bloomberg interview, you stated that Aladdin -- you see Aladdin pushing about $5 billion of revenue in the next 5 years. May be can you talk about what Aladdin would look like as a $5 billion revenue business? And maybe, what might be the grea
componenttext: Larry, in a Bloomberg interview, you stated that Aladdin -- you see Aladdin pushing about $5 billion of revenue in the next 5 years. May be can you talk about what Aladdin would look like as a $5 billion revenue business? And maybe, what might be the greatest risk that could prevent BlackRock from reaching these targets?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: I said that was an aspiration, let's be clear. And it was technology, not just Aladdin. So we believe what we are doing with our FutureAdvisor platform, with our iRetire platform, and of course, in Aladdin for wealth management, Aladdin for our institutio
componenttext: I said that was an aspiration, let's be clear. And it was technology, not just Aladdin. So we believe what we are doing with our FutureAdvisor platform, with our iRetire platform, and of course, in Aladdin for wealth management, Aladdin for our institutional clients, Aladdin provider for the custodial banking industry, we believe we have great growth potentials worldwide. As I said in my prepared remarks, we're seeing Aladdin interest in LatAm, in Europe. We have wealth management, Aladdin for wealth management integration going on right now in Asia. And so it's continuing to drive our platform, but where I'm most pleased, and I think has been the evolution of Aladdin beyond what its core competency was a few years back by allowing -- by having the ability to work with our wealth management clients and helping them having the analytical capacity to analyze the risk of every single client they have. And so especially in a world that is moving with MiFID II, with a world that is moving more towards advisory, less brokerage, I believe the need for greater oversight, greater understanding is going to be necessary and the Aladdin platform is one of the options that many people have to drive that technology knowledge. And then we will continue to do acquisitions. We have a few areas that we're looking at right now to further add opportunities that we have in technology. But let me just say importantly what technology is for BlackRock. It's the core of our culture, so -- and what I do believe with our clients are finding, when they have the Aladdin platform, and you have the singularity of one technology platform throughout an organization is driving our clients culture. And I do believe this is going to continue to drive a component of the growth that we see for Aladdin. So we're quite excited. At times, we're pretty overwhelmed with opportunities, but Mr. Goldstein and team have done a very good job in terms of driving those opportunities.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Craig Siegenthaler with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Craig Siegenthaler with Crédit Suisse.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: So if you look at BlackRock's strong AUM growth over the last 3 years and contrast it to the slower revenue and EPS growth trends, listen, we know large component of the delta was driven by onetime market factors like FX and divergent beta. But when you f
componenttext: So if you look at BlackRock's strong AUM growth over the last 3 years and contrast it to the slower revenue and EPS growth trends, listen, we know large component of the delta was driven by onetime market factors like FX and divergent beta. But when you focus just on the fee rate, can you provide us a rough estimate of the impact from the market-driven factors? And then also, decline-driven factors. When you think about negative mixed shift over its Core Series and fee cuts in. I'm just really looking for kind of ballpark figures here.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hey, Craig, it's Gary. Good morning. So maybe I'll take a crack at that for you. I think if we could start, recall from Investor Day, which was, I guess, about 9 months ago, we showed the chart at Investor Day that detailed how despite growth of about $1.
componenttext: Hey, Craig, it's Gary. Good morning. So maybe I'll take a crack at that for you. I think if we could start, recall from Investor Day, which was, I guess, about 9 months ago, we showed the chart at Investor Day that detailed how despite growth of about $1.3 billion in our base fees, and I think it was from 2012 to '15, so that chart is a little dated now. Despite that growth, our fee rate had actually declined by a little over one basis point. I think it was about 1.3 basis points. Organic growth drove about 30% of the revenue growth over that period of time, and actually, expanded our fee rate by about 1 basis point. That, I would basically refer you to as mixed shift, and that is a phenomenal where our organic base fee growth is actually growing faster than our organic asset growth, which frankly, with the exception of last year has done pretty continuously. While beta and FX drove about 70% of the revenue growth, which, again, are elements outside of our direct control. It actually caused a 2 basis point decline in the fee rate over the time period, and that is really what we talked about as being divergent beta and FX. It actually increases our revenue, but it actually decreases our fee rate. And if you think about it pretty simply, the S&P has significantly outperformed global and emerging markets, and we've seen significant dollars strengthening by somewhere between 20% and 25% versus the pound and the euro. And what does that do to us that actually causes our dollar-denominated assets to increase, which have lower fees versus products in Europe and Asia and especially in emerging markets. Now bear in mind over the time period, there really were no meaningful fee cuts to speak of. Obviously, we did launch the core in the fall of 2012. Last year, just to true-up that chart, the fee rate declined about 1 basis point despite another year of positive organic fee growth in a tough market. And I think we've talked a lot about that where the trends were generally the same. But if you look back, whether it was -- we really general organic fee base growth of 6% in '13 and '14 and '15. And while it dipped to 1% last year, we generated 5% organic base fee growth in the first quarter, and that's even with the fee cuts that we have announced both in fixed income and iShares. So I think the bottom line really is divergent beta and FX in many cases, which is repricing in some respects $5 trillion of assets every day. But I also think that we are, as Larry mentioned, we really feel that we're as well positioned as we've ever been to grow not only assets, but also base fees in a variety of markets and really differentiate ourselves in terms of organic growth through a variety of market cycles.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bill Katz with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bill Katz with Citi.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just coming back to the dynamics on fee rates for a moment. I think in the same article that Ken has reiterated likelihood of fee rates will continue to work lower in the industry, which I think is pretty widely understood now. So my question is, when you
componenttext: Just coming back to the dynamics on fee rates for a moment. I think in the same article that Ken has reiterated likelihood of fee rates will continue to work lower in the industry, which I think is pretty widely understood now. So my question is, when you start thinking about the conversations you're having with the retail the servitors at the point-of-sale -- around point-of-sale economics, what's happening with that dialogue? Because the way I see is that, that's sort of like a fixed rate, somewhere [indiscernible] 5 to 10 basis points, but as the management fee rates continues to work lower, that economic model is under a lot of strain in my view. And is technology the answer? How do you sort of think that plays out?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Look I mean, I think fee rate down. I think there is a reality of what's happening. Some of that is mixed shift, some of that is changing regulation in terms of distribution, some of that will ultimately -- will all accrue to the benefits, obviously, of t
componenttext: Look I mean, I think fee rate down. I think there is a reality of what's happening. Some of that is mixed shift, some of that is changing regulation in terms of distribution, some of that will ultimately -- will all accrue to the benefits, obviously, of the end client. I think ultimately, this comes down to our ability to generate sustainable Alpha. I think if we can generate sustainable Alpha in a way that that -- in some ways kind of captures 3 to 4x the the fee over time, I think will be fine. If we're in a period of significantly lower returns and lower sustainable Alpha, then, obviously, I think fee rates are going to have to come down accordingly.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: So let me just add to that. One of the things that is happening is that the financial advisers are looking for lower cost products. So first, there's a shift, and they need to go to a firm that has a wider range of products, both active and passive. And t
componenttext: So let me just add to that. One of the things that is happening is that the financial advisers are looking for lower cost products. So first, there's a shift, and they need to go to a firm that has a wider range of products, both active and passive. And then secondly, they need to look where they can find the best value at the best price. Both of those really bode well for BlackRock, and that is why Larry used the words in his brief, deliberate and strategic investments that we're making. So we are making those investments in those core type of products that we know the financial advisers will need to be able to do the appropriate asset allocation they need at the best value and the best price. So that shift is actually moving in our direction.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Let me just put it into a different context, too. I think this is missing in the narrative. There's a greater belief that long-term returns are structurally lower than they were 10 and 20 years ago. So if you have expected long-term return of, let's say,
componenttext: Let me just put it into a different context, too. I think this is missing in the narrative. There's a greater belief that long-term returns are structurally lower than they were 10 and 20 years ago. So if you have expected long-term return of, let's say, 6%, which many people think that might be high when you look at a balanced portfolio. Fees take up a lot of that return. And as long as we believe the world is going to be in a low return environment, our clients are under a lot of pressure and clients are looking for different ways of seeking those outcomes. And this is why I actually believe why more clients are coming to us now because they have this structural problem. There liability or their actuarial needs are greater than they can earn with our asset base, and so they're looking either to buy build, they're looking to have less expensive products. But there are looking for a much more holistic solution. And I think the era where a manager sold a product, a sold product that is what's being threatened today. And as Rob just said, we're in a great position with our clients to try to help them with these really difficult issues. We've had a couple state funds and announced that they're lowering their actuarially ill rates, that's very hard to do. If a state fund lowers their actuarial rate, that means they have to go to their unions and say, pay more. That means they have to go to the state and say, contribute more. And so this is one of the real issues that I think is being lost. It's being -- so when you talk about -- when we talk about fee pressure, fee pressure comes from the real issue of lower expected returns. And I think this is one of the big issues around hedge funds and why we are constantly reading about some hedge funds closing, some hedge funds are lowering their fees because the fee structures are just too large versus the returns on a risk-adjusted basis that they are achieving. So this is a broad-based issue. It's not just in the wealth management area, it's across a spectrum of clients. I wont belaboring this point, but I think it's a very important point. But this is the environment we all live in, and I think this is in an environment that really positioned BlackRock in a very differentiated way. So we understand this problem, we are dealing with this issue, and we're taking advantage of it. I'll leave it at that.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michael Carrier with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Carrier with Bank of America.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, may be a question just -- you mentioned in the past and more recently from investments unlike the tech side, artificial intelligence, machine learning. And just wanted to get a sense, when we think about that opportunity, are you looking at
componenttext: Yes, I guess, may be a question just -- you mentioned in the past and more recently from investments unlike the tech side, artificial intelligence, machine learning. And just wanted to get a sense, when we think about that opportunity, are you looking at it more from like a product -- from the active teams using those as tools, being able to help clients out? Is it a cost initiative? Just wanted to get some clarity reality on where do you see kind of the opportunities around some of these investments.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Let's be clear. Technology, pretty sufficiencies across everything. So we look at technology not just for portfolio, construction portfolio management, we're using it for client connectivity, we're using it for efficiencies within our platform. The techno
componenttext: Let's be clear. Technology, pretty sufficiencies across everything. So we look at technology not just for portfolio, construction portfolio management, we're using it for client connectivity, we're using it for efficiencies within our platform. The technology investments we've made in Aladdin related to dealing with a custodial bank saves us large sums of money, so I want to talk about. Technology is changing every component of our firm. And I think this is one of the reasons why our margins have been consistently strong by the utilization of technology across all the spectrums. You asked specifically related to technology, related to investing. Because the advancements to technology, because the utilization of sensor technology, because the Internet playing a role in everything and anything we do, there is information that we could not search for or find years ago whether it is communication by employees about their firms and consumer sentiments about a product. And so by having the ability to do deep dives on data, interpreting that data through different algorithms and models, hopefully that will be creating Alpha. As it creates products, it creates product turns, and so that's where we look at the greatest amount of investments. We're also looking at computers and can computers be learning and adapting in markets, but that's something for the future. But importantly, technology today for data analysis, technology for very quick analysis of that data is going to be really the key component of driving, I believe, returns and active investing in the future. And I do believe, because technology has created the efficiencies, it creates more efficiencies across, and we can't pass on this efficiencies also to our clients. And this is one thing is being missed. Here we are as we talk about some of the fee cuts and yet we have an increase of 100 basis points in margins. So we look at technology as a great efficiency provider for investing, for custodial assets, for communicating with our custodial clients, for communicating with our employees, for communicating with our clients. So it is the key element that is going to transform BlackRock, and I would say, every other financial services company. So technology is what is driving the scale at BlackRock, and it's driving, hopefully, better outcomes for and to our clients.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michael Cyprys with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Cyprys with Morgan Stanley.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: So Larry, you spoke about building blocks to deliver outcomes and greater use of ETFs to generate value. I guess, just few thoughts here. One is how far do you see the trend going? And I guess, the second, how do you think about the impact that this has o
componenttext: So Larry, you spoke about building blocks to deliver outcomes and greater use of ETFs to generate value. I guess, just few thoughts here. One is how far do you see the trend going? And I guess, the second, how do you think about the impact that this has on the value chain for the industry? In other words, if the shift towards asset allocation continues and the mood towards building blocks in assembly, how do you see the value shifting here and your ability to chart for manufacturing versus the ability to charge for distribution or your ability to charge our family and also the value of distribution here? Where is the most dispensable, and how do you think about evolving your positioning from here?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: So it's Rob here. So fees are really one aspect of the value proposition. And quite frankly, after many years in the business, I can't think of a better product to use for asset allocation than ETFs. So one is, it's going to be tool where we're going to u
componenttext: So it's Rob here. So fees are really one aspect of the value proposition. And quite frankly, after many years in the business, I can't think of a better product to use for asset allocation than ETFs. So one is, it's going to be tool where we're going to use it for our precision type investments where you can accent one specific area of the market in your portfolio. Two is that you can actually make better judgments in the Active Equity space by using what we would call smart beta ETF, so that would be a bit of a derivative to it, but focused on certain factors that you want to have. Three is that it's an obvious part of a multi-asset solution, which is a growing area of the market where you'd have just you need in order to get the returns that Larry is talking about in a low interest rate environment, you need to focus on specific sectors of the market and ETFs will allow you to do that at the right value. And the third thing, which I really like is in the fixed income area, where the exposure to just one particular fixed income bond is not going to give you that type of return. There's just too much risk from the cost of that. So by using an ETF in the asset allocation model in your fixed income portion, you also are diversifying your risk substantially at a much lower cost. Also, the world is moving more towards portfolio of construction capabilities. This is going to be what we're calling models that we're going to be offering. They offer much higher levels of risk management, and here is where we can utilize our technology as a differentiator. Because we can actually deliver a multi-asset solution, which has the right risk requirements for that particular client. And we're building technology around that. So you've heard us mention Aladdin portfolio builder where we're giving financial advisers the ability to take a multi-asset portfolio and put it together using our products, using other peoples' products to come up with the ultimate solution. We're using it in a product that we call iRetire, where we're trying to help get in the middle of solving probably the largest problem facing our country and others today, which is the lack of savings for retirement, getting those -- getting that cash and sitting on the sidelines, working for people for those people that are going to retire and being able to illustrate to financial advisors and their clients better capabilities to achieve those results. And then also, expanding into, giving model portfolios to the financial advisers and to our clients to use to solve their problems. So we have the technology on the outside. And then on the inside, we had precision instruments through the ETF business that can help our clients achieve their financial objectives.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: I just want to maybe talk -- ask [indiscernible] about the announcement and repositioning of the equities business in the U.S. And I guess, more specifically, the -- I mean, the changes you announced, I believe, really mainly to the U.S. business, and you
componenttext: I just want to maybe talk -- ask [indiscernible] about the announcement and repositioning of the equities business in the U.S. And I guess, more specifically, the -- I mean, the changes you announced, I believe, really mainly to the U.S. business, and you didn't -- I don't think you made same kind of changes outside the U.S. Can you maybe talk a little bit about why you didn't think some of that repositioning was may be necessary outside the U.S., how that business or market may be differs or different somewhat from what you're experiencing here maybe compared to the two?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hey, Rob, it's Gary. I'll just give a little bit of a quick overview and then Larry and Rob can jump in as they feel. I mean, I think ultimately, we're looking at both efficiencies and development and maturity of markets. And when we think here about the
componenttext: Hey, Rob, it's Gary. I'll just give a little bit of a quick overview and then Larry and Rob can jump in as they feel. I mean, I think ultimately, we're looking at both efficiencies and development and maturity of markets. And when we think here about the repositioning, it really follows much more along the line of how we approach our product segmentation work with iShares a number of years ago at the end of 2012. And in that case, it was really trying to align who the particular buyers or the product were with the right fees. And in this case, it was really trying to align our ability to generate sustainable Alpha in certain products with the fee potential. And so if you think about segmenting the products between kind of core Alpha and high conviction in some respects, I think it's somewhat of an acknowledgment that in many parts of the U.S., large cap markets, in particular, ability to really generate sustainable Alpha and still charge premium fees in terms of very broad-based portfolios that really tinker around indexes. I don't want investors to think index hugging per se, but your ability to take risk and generate incremental returns need to be much more closely aligned with the fee potential. And so it was really in that context that we really try to align fee with the ability to generate a certain level of sustainable Alpha. Outside of the U.S. market, in lesser developed markets, less efficient markets, less dispersion, less correlation I think we feel strongly in places like Europe and Asia and certain emerging markets that frankly, the ability to generate sustainable Alpha can support higher fees. And I think our performance has certainly showed that over time.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: So let me jump in there. So this is not just a U.S. announcement that we made, we're talking about our platform, Rob. And our platform is going forward, believing that both human and technology is better than one or the other. So in the platform, the port
componenttext: So let me jump in there. So this is not just a U.S. announcement that we made, we're talking about our platform, Rob. And our platform is going forward, believing that both human and technology is better than one or the other. So in the platform, the portfolio managers are going to be using going forward, they're going to have the ability to tap to both the data that we're getting from our technology, from our scientific active equity groups and the fundamental groups because we believe that those people talking together using the data, using the signals that we're getting and the block and tackle fundamental approach together are better than either individually. So it is a platform change that we made, it did have because of the reasons Gary cited, more immediate attention on the U.S., but it's a platform change that we're making globally in our active investment business.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Dan Fannon from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question is from Dan Fannon from Jefferies.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on kind of Aladdin and the technology business. As more clients adopt a platform, at what point does the platform become too big or there's been articles out there about potentially introducing systemic risk into the system if everyb
componenttext: Just a quick question on kind of Aladdin and the technology business. As more clients adopt a platform, at what point does the platform become too big or there's been articles out there about potentially introducing systemic risk into the system if everybody's on your platform that they're using the same tool, technology that you guys are building.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, that's pretty complex question, so I don't think there is a risk of it too big, so let me try to deconstruct your question. Aladdin is more than just a risk management platform, it's an enterprise platform. So, A, there are many companies that provi
componenttext: Well, that's pretty complex question, so I don't think there is a risk of it too big, so let me try to deconstruct your question. Aladdin is more than just a risk management platform, it's an enterprise platform. So, A, there are many companies that provide enterprise platform for different companies, whether it's Oracle or SAP or cloud computing, so an enterprise system, and that's what Aladdin really is because it's a front and back office platform and a component of it is risk management. I think you're referring to the risk management component of it. It's a service model. We provide with different models each individual client can put their own algorithms onto a Aladdin that are customized for them. So they can interpret the models, so it's not a platform that is monolithic with one model. And so the notion that the fact that many people use it that it becomes systemic is just not a point of understanding what a platform really is. I think by the clients interest, the opportunities we have, the opportunities as large as ever, and it is because of its enterprise solution. And as we now have Aladdin provider working with the custodial banks, ultimately, it's going to simplify our trading -- trade entry, compliance, working alongside with a custodial bank, we create so much more efficiencies for the users across the Aladdin system. So if we could provide for Aladdin, for all the clients this enterprise system that creates these taped efficiencies that make them in a better position, we're all better off from it. So it's, once again, Aladdin as a service model, it's not BlackRock's models. So I think we have -- we're happy to give you a demo on Aladdin, what it is and what it isn't.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017

componenttext: Our final question comes from Patrick Davitt with Autonomous.

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the active repositioning and the charges taken there as well as the move of the cost of the assets to JPMorgan, I'm curious if all of these moves are really about helping pass those savings on to the client and absorb the fee cuts we're talking about,
componenttext: On the active repositioning and the charges taken there as well as the move of the cost of the assets to JPMorgan, I'm curious if all of these moves are really about helping pass those savings on to the client and absorb the fee cuts we're talking about, or should we start to see some visible improvement to your operating results because of these moves?

headline: BlackRock, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2017
componenttextpreview: Patrick, it's Gary. I'm hoping that you'll see both. I mean, as Rob said, part of repositioning the active portfolio was basically trying to use scale to bring better outcomes to clients, obviously, in terms of better sustainable Alpha at a more efficient
componenttext: Patrick, it's Gary. I'm hoping that you'll see both. I mean, as Rob said, part of repositioning the active portfolio was basically trying to use scale to bring better outcomes to clients, obviously, in terms of better sustainable Alpha at a more efficient price point for them. But the intent the end of the day is to generate incremental growth for BlackRock shareholders by having a better value proposition in terms of pricing performance that we think ultimately will drive better organic growth. In terms of some of the things you mentioned around just leveraging service providers in many cases in certain instances our clients pay those fees in which case that will be a direct benefit for them and in a certain cases, it's as if our ETF, which is a unitary price structure BlackRock itself pays those fees so our shareholders will clearly benefit. So I think that in all cases, we're going to basically try to use our scale to drive growth. That growth is ultimately better for both clients as well as shareholders. And I think as you look at margin expansion over -- whether it's just the last year-over-year where it's 100 basis points or frankly, ever since we closed the BGI deal at the end of 2009, margins are probably up 400 to 500-plus basis points since then and I think there's no question that we're using our scale to generate better outcomes for both clients and shareholders. So it's good for the client at the end of the day. We strongly believe it's going to be good for the BlackRock shareholders.

componenttext:
Yes. Thank you for all joining us this morning and for your continued interest in our firm. Our first quarter results, once again, highlights the investments we made to enhance a differentiation of BlackRock's diverse global platform. We continue to take a long-term view while staying ahead of navigating near term developments in the financial and economic landscape on behalf of our clients, and importantly, on behalf of our shareholders. 
So with that, have a good quarter.
